Selected Answer: C
A. Disable idle-timeout: While idle timeout can be configured, it is not specifically required for ADVPN to work.
B. Set ike-version to 1: ADVPN works with both IKEv1 and IKEv2, but IKEv2 is preferred for modern implementations.
D. Enable net-device: The net-device setting is usually disabled in ADVPN deployments because it is used in scenarios where the FortiGate is aware of the underlying network topology, which is not needed in this case.
Page 243
Selected Answer C

net-device must be enabled if you want to support ADVPN shortcuts in SD-WAN.

questions.question_text: Which statement about using BGP for ADVPN is true?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
IBGP is Preferred for ADVPN
✅ Single AS Environment – ADVPN deployments typically involve spokes and hubs within a single organization, meaning they usually belong to the same Autonomous System (AS).
✅ Route Reflectors (RR) Support – IBGP allows the hub to act as a route reflector, reducing the need for full mesh IBGP sessions among spokes.
✅ Consistent Policies – Easier to manage and apply consistent routing policies across all spokes.
✅ Better Control Over Path Selection – IBGP allows finer control of routes via local preference, which is useful for SD-WAN path selection.

Selected Answer: A
obviously A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct, this is detailed on page 240 in the 7.2 Study Guide.

choices.A: IBGP is preferred over EBGP, because IBGP preserves next hop information.
choices.B: You must configure AS path prepending.
choices.D: You must use BGP to route traffic for both overlay and underlay links.

choices.C: There are no IPsec tunnel statistics log messages for ADVPN shortcuts.
choices.B: The master tunnel T_INET_0 cannot accept the ADVPN shortcut.
choices.D: The VPN tunnel T_MPLS_0 is a shortcut tunnel.
choices.A: There is one shortcut tunnel built from master tunnel T_MPLS_0.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/7.2.0/new-features/661245/add-log-field-to-identify-advpn-shortcuts-in-vpn-logs
'A value of 1 indicates the tunnel is an ADVPN shortcut, and 0 indicates it is not'

Selected Answer: D
I did not find anything in the text book referencing a "master tunnel" on page 283 it clearly states that a tunnel is assigned 1 for shortcut tunnel and 0 for normal tunnel. Therefore D is correct.

comments.content: How can someone write such a long text, appear reassuring, but be completely wrong. The answer is D. study guide p283

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Explanation:
Line 8:The log entry shows an IPsec tunnel named "T_MPLS_0", with an advpnc=1.
This indicates that the tunnel T_MPLS_0 is being used as a master tunnel and has created a shortcut tunnel for ADVPN.
The presence of advpnc=1 confirms the shortcut tunnel.
Why not the other options?
B. The master tunnel T_INET_0 cannot accept the ADVPN shortcut.
Incorrect. The logs do not indicate that T_INET_0 is incapable of ADVPN shortcuts. The advpnc=0 simply means no shortcut was created for that particular tunnel.
C. There are no IPsec tunnel statistics log messages for ADVPN shortcuts.
Incorrect. The log entry for T_MPLS_0 clearly shows an advpnc=1, confirming the presence of an ADVPN shortcut.
D. The VPN tunnel T_MPLS_0 is a shortcut tunnel.
Incorrect. T_MPLS_0 is a master tunnel, and a shortcut tunnel is built from it.
Thus, A is the correct answer because there is one shortcut tunnel built from T_MPLS_0 as indicated by advpnc=1 in the logs

Selected Answer: D
D is indeed the correct answer
we've been so used to tunnel names with NAME_NUMBER, thus the confusion that letter A is the correct one

but we need to remember that as long as advpnsc=1, that means that tunnel is a shortcut tunnel. for this example, the parent tunnel is likely named only T_MPLS (no number)

Selected Answer: D
SG p 283: "the field advpnsc will help you identify the shortcut VPN tunnels. FG will set advpnsc value 1 for . . . shortcut tunnels."
Given that T_MPLS_0 is marked with advpnsec=1, this log entry confirms that it is indeed an ADVPN shortcut tunnel. D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
A is wrong, because the name of master should be T_MPLS.
Shortcut tunnel name is T_MPLS_0

D is correct
 When reviewing VPN log messages, the field advpnsc will help you identify the shortcut VPN tunnels.
FortiGate will set advpnsc value 1 for any log messages related to shortcut tunnels; for any other tunnel, the
advpnsc value is set to 0.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, advpnsc=1 means shortcut, vpntunnel="T_MPLS_O" name of the tunnel

Selected Answer: A
There is one shortcut built over T_MPLS_0 because second log has "advpnsc=1" and page 283 says "FortiGate will set advpnsc value 1 for any log messages related to shortcut tunnels; for any other tunnel, the advpnsc value is set to 0."

comments.content: Answer A seems to be correct. T_MPLS_0 is a parent tunnel from spoke to the hub. The shortcut tunnel should have a sub-tunnel name such as T_MPLS_0_0
it's wrong because a shortcut built over T_MPLS_0 should be T_MPLS_0_0. Instead T_MPLS_0 is the shortcut

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct answer is D - advpnsc=1 means that it is a shortcut.
Correct answer is A

choices.D: It enables spokes to bypass the hub during shortcut negotiation.
choices.B: It enables spokes to establish shortcuts to third-party gateways.
choices.A: It provides the benefits of a full-mesh topology in a hub-and-spoke network.
choices.C: It provides direct connectivity between spokes by creating shortcuts.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A: is correct, this is because spokes create shortcuts through hub and spoke topologies giving the benefit of full mesh in a hub and spoke environment. page 266
B: is incorrect, this is because it does not need third party gateways to establish the short cut. 
C: is correct for the same reason A is.
D: is incorrect because it still needs to pass the hub to establish the shortcut.
A & C are correct

Selected Answer: AC
Correct Answer is A & C

AC correct

questions.question_text: In a hub-and-spoke topology, what are two advantages of enabling ADVPN on the IPsec overlays? (Choose two.)

choices.C: FortiGate bounces port5 after it detects all SD-WAN members as dead.
choices.A: FortiGate brings down port5 after it detects all SD-WAN members as dead.
choices.D: FortiGate fails over to the secondary device after it detects all SD-WAN members as dead.
choices.B: FortiGate brings up port5 after it detects all SD-WAN members as alive.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct, it configures port 5 as an alert interface. Therefore if all interfaces die it brings down the alert. If one is alive it brings it back up.

Selected Answer: A
set update-cascade-interface enable → This ensures that if all SD-WAN members fail (e.g., members 1, 2, and 3), FortiGate will trigger a fail-detection mechanism.
Since port5 is set as a fail-alert interface, it will be brought down when all SD-WAN members are detected as dead.

comments.content:
Wrong, to quote
FortiGate brings down alert interfaces if ALL members are dead
and brings it back up if at least one is alive

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D
Base on the study guide
Cascade Interfaces based on the configuration shown in the previous slide. If 
there is at least one alive member—the alert interface (port5) is up. 
However, if all members are dead, port5 is brought down.

Selected Answer: A
A. is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct as explained on page 116 in the SD-WAN 7.2 Study guide.

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A, study guide SD-WAN 7.2 page 116
